TI: Estrogen receptor-alpha is localized to neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.
AB: The female predominance for developing Alzheimer disease (AD) suggests the involvement of gender specific factor(s) such as a reduced estrogen-estrogen receptor signaling in the pathogenesis of AD. The potential role of ERalpha in AD pathogenesis has been explored by several groups with mixed results. We revisited this issue of expression and distribution of ERalpha in AD brain using a specific ERalpha antibody. Interestingly, we found that ERalpha co-localized with neurofibrillary pathology in AD brain and further demonstrated that ERalpha interacts with tau protein in vivo. Immunoprecipitaion experiments found increased ERalpha-tau interaction in the AD cases, which may account for ERalpha being sequestered in neuronal tau pathology. Indeed, tau overexpression in M17 cells leads to interruption of estrogen signaling. Our data support the idea that sequestration of ERalpha by tau pathology underlies the loss of estrogen neuroprotection during the course of AD.
